column3:
I'm still confused why this is needed. I've been running a node on a FreeBSD machine for years, and never had to redefine `MAKE`.

A clean checkout of master on FreeBSD 12.0-RELEASE-p10:
```
user@medea:~/src/bitcoin % echo $MAKE
MAKE: Undefined variable.
user@medea:~/src/bitcoin % ./autogen.sh
â€¦
user@medea:~/src/bitcoin % ./configure --disable-wallet --disable-dependency-tracking\

@murrayn There are at least two ./configure examples in each doc file and more can be added later on, imho it just clutters the documentation but it can be changed if deemed necessary. On top of that csh is the default shell on BSDs and compiling bitcoin from source requires some knowledge of the OS anyway.\n\n@laanwj You ran ./configure with --disable-dependency-tracking which won't trigger the
So it's an alternative for `--disable-dependency-tracking`? Makes sense then.
I agree with the other commenters in using [`./configure MAKE=gmake`](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/14404#issuecomment-431565631).

`setenv` is not portable between shells. Yes, it works on the default `csh` but does not work in others.\n\nGiven that `./configure MAKE=gmake` is an equivalent and works with any shell, I would suggest to add `MAKE=gmake` a few lines below where we show how to execute `./configure`.
